## **Previously on 201**
<br>
.pull-left[
- **different meanings in languages**<br><br>
  1. literal meaning (semantics)<br><br>
  2. implied meaning (pragmatics)<br><br>
  3. social meaning (sociolinguistics)<br><br>
- **semantic relations** <br><br>
  1. synonym *<u>drinks</u>* vs. *<u>beverages</u>*<br><br>
  2. hypernym *<u>universities</u>* to *<u>Rutgers</u>*<br><br>
  3. hyponym *<u>jeans</u>* to *<u>pants</u>* <br><br>
  4. antonym

]
.pull-right[
- **entailment**: sentence **p** entails sentence **q** <span style="color:green"><b>iff</b></span> **q** is true <span style="color:green"><b>whenever</b></span> **p** is true.<br><br>
  - world-specific entailment (**q** entails **p**)
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*p*</b></span>: The water is <span style="color:blue"><b>hot</b></span> <u>now</u>.
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*q*</b></span>: The water is <span style="color:blue"><b>boiled</b></span> <u>now</u><br><br>
  - logical entailment  (**p** entails **q**)
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*p*</b></span>: He finished <span style="color:blue"><b>all</b></span> his homework.
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*q*</b></span>: He finished <span style="color:blue"><b>some of</b></span> his homework.<br><br>
  - mutual entailment
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*p*</b></span>: Mary is <span style="color:blue"><b>older</b></span> than John.
  
  <span style="color:green"><b>*q*</b></span>: John is <span style="color:blue"><b>younger</b></span> than Mary.<br><br>
]

## **SET**
<br>
.pull-left[
A word's **reference** is the <span style="color:green"><b>SET</b></span> of entities (referents) that the word refers to.
<br><br>
A <span style="color:green"><b>SET</b></span> is <u>a collection/list of items<br><br>
In **mathematics**:

- a <span style="color:green"><b>SET</b></span> needs to be **well-defined**
- meaning there is at least one **commonality** among all items.<br><br>

- {2, 4, 6, 8, 10,...} [the set of even numbers]<br><br>

Yet in **semantics**:

- a **list** is also considered a <span style="color:green"><b>SET</b></span><br><br>
- {legitmate, 3x=5, OIIAI-cat.GIF, *never-gonna-give-you-up.MP4*}
]

## **Set Theory**
<br>
.pull-left[
1. in a set, **order** of items <span style="color:green"><b>does not</b></span> matter
  - {a, b, c} = {a, c, b} = {b, a, c} = {b, c, a} = {c, a, b} = {c, b, a} 
<br><br>
2. **repetitions** of items <span style="color:green"><b>do not</b></span> count as 'separate' items.
  - {a, b, c} = {a, a, a, b, c} = {a, b, b, c, c}
<br><br>
3. An <span style="color:green"><b>ITEM</b></span> in a set is called the **MEMEBER** of that set
  - and we use symbol **∈** to describe membership relation <br><br>
  - a **∈** {a, b, c}
  - a **is in** / <span style="color:green"><b>belongs to</b></span> / <span style="color:green"><b>is an element of</b></span> the set {a, b, c}
]
.pull-right[

]

## **Set Theory**
<br>
.pull-left[
### **List Notation**
<br>
The **list notation** specifies a set by <span style="color:green">listing its members</span>  between {curly brackets}<br><br>
  - The set <span style="color:green">*T*</span> is characters in ***Tom and Jerry***
  - <span style="color:green">*T*</span> = {Tom, Jerry, Tuffy, Spike, Tyke, Butch, Quacker, Cuckoo...}
<br><br>

<img src="../pic/1024/tom.gif" width="22%"><img src="../pic/1024/jerry.gif" width="22%"><img src="../pic/1024/spike.gif" width="22%"><img src="../pic/1024/tyke.gif" width="22%">
]

.pull-right[
### **Predicate Notation**
<br>
The **predicate notation** specifies a set by <span style="color:green">listing its members</span><br><br>
- <span style="color:green">*S*</span> = { x **|** x is a sorcerer }
- "<span style="color:green">*S*</span> equals the set of elements <span style="color:blue"><b>*x*</b></span>, such that **every** <span style="color:blue"><b>*x*</b></span> is a sorcerer"
- normal words: "the set of all sorcerers"
- **|** stands for "*<u>such that</u>*" 
<br><br>

## **Set Theory**: relations between two sets
.pull-left[
### **subset (⊆)**:
- A is a subset of B if **every** element of A is **also** an element of B
  - {a, b} **⊆** {a, b, c}
  - {a, b} **⊆** {a, b}
  - **~~a ⊆ {a, b, c}~~**, this is **WRONG**, because **a** is not a set

### **proper subset (⊂)**:
- A is a proper subset of B if A is a **subset** of B and they are not **identical**
  - {a, b} **⊆** {a, b, c}

### **identity (=)**:
- two sets are identical/equal if they have **exactly the same** elements
  - {a, b} **=** {b, a}
]

  <img src="../pic/1024/set.jpg" width="85%">
]

## **Set Operations: (∪<span style="color:white">aa</span>∩<span style="color:white">aa</span>-<span style="color:white">aa</span>')**
<br>

--

### <span style="color:green"><b>union (∪)</b></span>
- produces a new set which contains <span style="color:green"><b>all elements</b></span> that belong to <span style="color:green"><b>both sets</b></span> (including elements in both sets)<br><br>

--

### <span style="color:blue"><b>intersection (∩)</b></span>
- produces a new set that <span style="color:blue"><b>only contains</b></span> elements that belong to <span style="color:blue"><b>BOTH</b></span> sets<br><br>

--

### <span style="color:orange"><b>difference (-)</b></span>
- the difference of A and B is a new set which contains all elements that <span style="color:orange"><b>belong to A</b></span>, but <span style="color:orange"><b>NOT B</b></span>
- A - B is <span style="color:orange"><b>not</b></span> equal to B - A in most cases<br><br>

--

### **complement (')**
- produces a new set which contains all elements in the **relevant universe** that are **NOT** in the set

## **Set Theory**: relations between two sets
<br>
.pull-left[
### **cardinality**: the number of elements in a set
<br>
- if A = {a, b, c}

  then the **cardinality** of the set A, **|A|** = 3
  
  also, **|A|** = **|{a, b, c}|**<br><br>
- <span style="color:green"><b>singleton set</b></span>: a set with cardinality = 1
- <span style="color:green"><b>null set</b></span> <span style="color:green"><b>empty set</b></span>: a set with cardinality = 0
  - {} = **Ø** "empty set"
]

## **Composition of meanings**
### sentence type I (proper name subjects)
<br>
.pull-left[
**"name is NOUN"**
- [[name]] ∈ [[NOUN]]
- "Arthur is a king."
  - [[Arthur]] ∈ [[king]]
<br><br>

<span style="color:orange"><b>"name VERB"</b></span>
- [[name]] ∈ [[VERB]]
- "Arthur sleeps."
  - [[Arthur]] ∈ [[sleep]]
<br><br>

<span style="color:green"><b>"name is ADJECTIVE"</b></span>
- [[name]] ∈ [[ADJ]]
- "Arthur is happy"
  - [[Arthur]] ∈ [[happy]]
]

## **Composition of meanings**
### sentence type II (common noun subjects)
<br>
.pull-left[
  <img src="../pic/1024/verb.png" width="80%">
]
.pull-right[
**"name is NOUN"**
- [[NOUN]] ∈ [[NOUN]]
- "sorcerers are winners."
  - [[sorcerer]] ∈ [[winner]]
<br><br>

<span style="color:orange"><b>"name VERB"</b></span>
- [[NOUN]] ∈ [[VERB]]
- "sorcerers giggle."
  - [[sorcerer]] ⊆ [[giggle]]
<br><br>

<span style="color:green"><b>"name is ADJECTIVE"</b></span>
- [[NOUN]] ∈ [[ADJ]]
- "sorcerers are evil"
  - [[sorcerer]] ⊆ [[evil]]
]

## **Composition of meanings**
### sentence type III (complex sentences)
<br>
.pull-left[
<span style="color:orange"><b>"name is ADJECTIVE NOUN"</b></span>
- [[name]] **∈** [[ADJ]] **∩** [[NOUN]]
- "Arthur is a famous king."
  - [[Arthur]] **∈** [[famous]] **∩** [[king]]
<br><br>

<span style="color:green"><b>"ADJECTIVE NOUNs are ADJECTIVE"</b></span>
- [[ADJ]] **∩** [[NOUN]] **⊆** [[NOUN]]
- "Evil sorcerers are terrible"
  - [[evil]] **∩** [[sorcerer]] **⊆** [[terrible]]
]
